explanation: The most important part that everything else is built on.
The way a person or thing reacts in a certain situation.
You can count on it to work the same way every single time.
Something that takes a lot of work, energy, or time.
Shows the specific reason why one thing is different from another.
Deciding exactly what is included and what is left out.
The limits that show where one thing ends and another begins.
Two different things that work better when they are used together.
The usual way people do a specific job or task.
When something is true most of the time or for most of a group.
Moving or looking in the direction of a goal.
Things that are happening right now in the present time.
A sequence of steps where data or work moves from start to finish.
The ability for a system to get much bigger without breaking.
Testing to make sure new changes didn't break things that used to work.
Something that works sometimes but fails other times for no clear reason.
Something that is constantly moving or updating, not staying still.
A strict set of rules and methods used to check if things work.
Based on real-world evidence and facts rather than just ideas.
Something that has been around and accepted for a long time.
A group made up of many different types of things.
When two or more things cannot work without the help of the others.
Doing something because you wanted to, not by accident.
Holding onto something so it isn't lost or thrown away.
Things you are required to have before you can start something else.
To take or create something based on a different source.
Something that isn't clear because it could mean several things.
Something new that is just beginning to appear or become known.
Depending entirely on the specific situation you are in.
Used to show that something happened even if there was a reason to stop it.
Something important enough that you should pay attention to it.
Stated so clearly that there is no doubt about the meaning.
Linking two ideas or things together in your mind.
A word used to show that one action caused a specific result.
A word used to compare two things that are different.
Keeping something in its original, good condition.
A way to solve a problem or cure a sickness.
Something that almost never happens.
To have control over how something is done or run.
The system of rules and people that control an organization.
The way something is seen or understood by people.
A set of rules or a government that manages how things work.
The parts that add up to make a whole thing.
A word used to ask or tell who owns something.
The possible effects or consequences of an action.
Something that makes people not want to do something bad.
When something multiplies or spreads very quickly.
Weakening something so that it is no longer steady or safe.
When a process or rule repeats by going back into itself.
Two things happening together as a result of each other.
Doing something with great attention to detail and high standards.
When something has been carefully examined by a pro to make sure it's okay.
To cleverly avoid or escape from something.
The act of finding and bringing back something that was stored.
Something that is very bad, harsh, or extreme.
Reaching a final result after a long period of work.
Organized by levels, from the most important to the least.
Large collections of written texts used for study.
An event that marks a very important change in history or a process.
Bringing separate parts together to act as a single unit.
The specific things you are trying to achieve.
To gain ownership or knowledge of something new.
Something that appears as a result of many smaller parts working together.
Using a computer or brain to figure out a mathematical answer.
Provides the solid foundation that holds everything else up.
Related to the process of thinking, learning, and understanding.
Objects or pieces of work made by humans or processes.
Letters added to the start of a word to change its meaning.
Basic building blocks of a computer program that acts like a brain.
Moving or working in two opposite directions at once.
The study of whether an idea is actually possible to complete.
Relating to the actual meaning of language rather than just its sounds.
To absorb or swallow information or data into a system.
In testing, a source that tells you what the correct result should be.
To add something new into an already existing group or plan.
When one thing needs another thing to work properly.
Being conscious of what is happening around you.
Putting similar things into small groups together.
Something that changes its look but keeps the same core rules.
Based on things that actually happened and are real.
Something that was made up or invented to deceive people.
A confident statement that something is true.
To continue to exist or happen for a long time.
Very advanced and complicated in a clever way.
Getting in the way and making progress difficult.
Used to show a contrast between two ideas.
Failing to take care of or pay attention to something.
Using one specific thing as the main center of attention.
Something that was forgotten or intentionally not included.
A spiritual or philosophical word for being completely full.
Adding to something in a way that makes it better or complete.
The collection of books and papers on a certain subject.
Looking at the quality or traits of something rather than numbers.
Measuring something by how much or how many there are.
To keep something in your possession or memory.
When a middle person or thing helps two sides reach a result.
When two different things meet at a certain point.
To give a result or provide a product.
Something original that has never been seen before.
The process of something moving from a center to cover a wide area.
The standard procedure or rules that must be followed.
Not having the right qualities for a specific job.
Made up of many different and unlike parts.
Being held back or forced to stay within certain limits.
Single examples or occurrences of something.
To claim that something is true during a debate.
A word used to show that the next statement follows logically.
A very important part that everything else depends on.
To receive the worst or strongest part of something bad.
Serious talk or writing about a specific subject.
Something that happens again and again over time.
Coming after something else in time or order.
The curved path or direction that something follows over time.
An opinion or emotion expressed about a situation.
To be likely to behave in a certain way.
To forcibly stop or put an end to something.
A state where you are not sure what is true or what will happen.
Using three different methods to find a very accurate answer.
Organized according to a specific subject or theme.
Including everything that is necessary; complete.
Something so important that you cannot function without it.
Looking or asking very deeply to find hidden information.
